title: What’s that ringing in your ears? - Marc Fagelson

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: That the fever is caused by a virus.

options.label: D
options.text: That the fever is caused by a bacterial infection.

options.label: C
options.text: The causal fallacy.

title: What if you stopped drinking water?

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: To monitor the amount of sodium and other substances in the body

options.label: B
options.text: It shrinks and becomes less responsive

options.label: C
options.text: It remains the same and functions normally

title: Max and the Tag-Along Moon - Children's books read aloud

multiple-choice.question: What was Max doing when he first saw the moon in the sky behind his grandfather?

options.label: C
options.text: He was getting into the car.

options.label: B

title: What can DNA tests really tell us about our ancestry? - Prosanta Chakrabarty

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of our genome is shared among all humans?
What is the process called when chromosomes within each pair swap some sections as they go from a cell with 46 chromosomes to a sex cell with only 23 chromosomes?

options.label: A
options.text: Mutation

options.label: B
options.text: Recombination

options.label: C
options.text: Genetic drift

options.label: D
options.text: Natural selection

multiple-choice.question: Why can one sister be 10% more French than the other, even if they share the same parents and ancestors?

options.label: A
options.text: Because of differences in their DNA sequencing

options.label: B
options.text: Because of recombination, which makes each sister's chromosomes different from each other's

options.label: C
options.text: Because of differences in their ancestry

options.label: D
options.text: Because of differences in their genetic markers

multiple-choice.question: What do commercial DNA tests utilize?

options.label: A
options.text: Less than 1% of our entire genome

options.label: B
options.text: Less than 1% of the 1% of our genome that varies

options.label: C
options.text: Less than 1% of the 99% of our genome that is shared among all humans

options.label: D
options.text: Less than 1% of the 1% of our genome that makes us different

multiple-choice.question: Why can't DNA tests reveal heritage from people not represented in the database?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the test is not sensitive enough

options.label: B
options.text: Because the test is not accurate enough

options.label: C
options.text: Because many indigenous peoples are barely represented, if at all

options.label: D
options.text: Because the test is not designed to do so

title: Vowel-rr | Learn to read

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the vowel sound when the letter "R" is added to a word?

options.text: The vowel sound becomes longer.

options.label: B
options.text: The vowel sound becomes shorter.

options.label: C
options.text: The vowel sound stays the same.

options.label: D
options.text: The vowel sound disappears.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when two "R"s are together in a word?

options.label: A
options.text: One "R" controls the vowel.

options.label: B
options.text: The vowel sound becomes longer.

options.label: C
options.text: The vowel sound stays the same.

options.label: D
options.text: The vowel sound becomes a short sound again.

options.label: A
options.text: The vowel sound becomes longer.

options.label: B
options.text: The vowel sound becomes shorter.

options.label: C
options.text: The vowel sound stays the same.

options.label: D
options.text: The vowel sound disappears.

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: The vowel sound becomes longer.

options.label: B
options.text: The vowel sound becomes shorter.

options.label: C
options.text: The vowel sound stays the same.

options.label: D

title: Why do we have belly buttons?

multiple-choice.question: Why do humans and many other animals have belly buttons?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are a necessary part of our digestive system.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they help us breathe and eat.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are a scar left behind from the umbilical cord.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are a unique feature of our species.

multiple-choice.question: What is the umbilical cord, and what is its purpose?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a tube that carries food and water from the mother to the baby.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a tube that carries oxygen and nutrients from the mother to the baby.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a tube that carries air and waste from the baby to the mother.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a tube that connects the baby's heart to the mother's heart.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the umbilical cord after a baby is born?

options.label: A
options.text: It is reattached to the mother's body.

options.label: B
options.text: It is left intact and continues to provide oxygen and nutrients to the baby.

options.label: C
options.text: It is cut and falls off after a few weeks.

options.label: D
options.text: It is absorbed into the baby's body.

multiple-choice.question: Why do animals that lay eggs, such as birds and reptiles, not have belly buttons?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are not mammals and therefore do not have an umbilical cord.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they hatch from eggs and do not develop inside their mother's womb.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are too small to have a belly button.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they do not need a belly button to survive.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the belly button in humans and other animals?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a useful feature that helps us breathe and eat.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a scar left behind from the umbilical cord and serves as a reminder of our connection to our mother.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a necessary part of our digestive system.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a unique feature of our species that has no practical purpose.

title: When is a pandemic over?

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, when will the World Health Organization (WHO) declare the pandemic over?

options.label: A
options.text: Once the infection is mostly contained and rates of transmission drop significantly throughout the world.

options.label: B
options.text: Once the virus is completely eradicated.

options.label: C
options.text: Once 40-90% of the population has received a vaccine.

options.label: D
options.text: Once the death toll reaches a certain number.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary goal of the "Delay and Vaccinate" strategy?

options.label: A
options.text: To allow people to be exposed to the virus as quickly as possible.

options.label: B
options.text: To slow the spread of the virus to give research facilities time to produce a vaccine.

options.label: C
options.text: To coordinate responses among countries to starve the virus.

options.label: D
options.text: To restrict travel and quarantine the infected.

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated number of deaths that could occur if the "Race through it" strategy is implemented?

options.label: A
options.text: Hundreds of thousands

options.label: B
options.text: Millions to hundreds of millions

options.label: C
options.text: Thousands

options.label: D
options.text: Tens of thousands

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the primary advantage of the "Coordinate and Crush" strategy?

options.label: A
options.text: It can end a pandemic in just a few months with low loss of life.

options.label: B
options.text: It can eradicate the virus completely.

options.label: C
options.text: It can slow the spread of the virus to give research facilities time to produce a vaccine.

options.label: D
options.text: It can restrict travel and quarantine the infected.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary advantage of the "Delay and Vaccinate" strategy?

options.label: A
options.text: It can end a pandemic in just a few months with low loss of life.

options.label: B
options.text: It can eradicate the virus completely.

options.label: C
options.text: It can slow the spread of the virus to give research facilities time to produce a vaccine.

options.label: D
options.text: It can restrict travel and quarantine the infected.
